questions.question: How does gravity support life on Earth?

choices.answer: by forcing Earth to spin on its axis
by causing changes in the distance between Earth and the sun
by keeping water and gases near Earth's atmosphere
by preventing meteors & comets from hitting Earth’s surface

questions.question: Why are there high and low tides on Earth?

choices.answer: Due to changes in the moon’s tilt on its axis.
Due to the gravitational pull between Earth and the moon.
Due to the magnetic force between Earth and the moon.
Due to changes in the moon’s speed every month.

questions.question: Which contributes to Earth’s ability to sustain life?

choices.answer: Atmosphere prevents the sun’s radiation to enter.
The atmosphere stops space debris from reaching the surface.
Atmosphere is very thin due to the temperatures of the sun.
Atmosphere is breathable due to the unique mixture of gases.

questions.question: Which properties are most important to sustaining life on Earth?

choices.answer: Time of revolution & distance from the sun.
Distance from the sun and surface structure.

questions.question: NASA is responsible for the space program in the US What was the goal of NASA’s Apollo program?

choices.answer: To search for life on planets other than Earth
To land on a planet in another solar system
To determine the composition the Sun
To send a human to land on the Moon

questions.question: To which planet do (NASA) scientists hope to send humans next?
If the Earth didn't tilt on its axis in relation to the sun, which would be true?

choices.answer: The Earth would spin at a different rate.
Temperatures at the Earth’s equator would cool.

questions.question: A year on Earth is best described as the time it takes for which to occur?

choices.answer: the planet to revolve once around the Sun
the seasons to complete a full cycle
the planet to rotate once on its axis
the Sun to rotate once on its axis

questions.question: What keeps the planets in orbit around the Sun?
The Moon is in orbit around Earth. What keeps the Moon from changing its orbit?
Winter occurs in the Northern Hemisphere when it is _______________.

choices.answer: farthest away from the sun in Earth's orbit
on the dark side of Earth

questions.question: When it is spring in the Northern Hemisphere what season is it in the Southern Hemisphere?
Which statement is true regarding the moon's orbit?

choices.answer: The moon changes direction every time it becomes  full moon.
The moon orbits Earth, which revolves around the sun.
The moon does not orbit it.
The moon orbits around the sun.

questions.question: A scientist observes the same craters on the moon every day because ______.

choices.answer: the moon does not rotate on its axis
the moon has craters on only one side
the moon revolves at the same rate as the earth
the moon takes the same time to rotate and revolve

questions.question: How many times does the Moon rotate on its axis in one month?
When is Earth's axis tilted neither toward nor away from the sun?
When does the longest night of the year occur?
What makes Earth distinct from the other planets?

choices.answer: It has an atmosphere & moderate temperatures on the surface.
It's the only planet that orbits clockwise around the sun.
Only Earth is spherical in shape.
Only planet that has a moon

questions.question: High & low tides that occur at either a full moon or new moon:
An ecilpse in which the moon passes directly behind the earth into the shadow of the earth:
What phase of the moon that is more than half but less than fully illuminated?
A phase of the moon that is less than half illuminated:
Phase of the moon is which half of the moon's light is visible:
Phase of the moon in which all of the moon's illuminated surface is visible on earth:
The darkest part of a shadow in which all light is not visible during an eclipse.
